noun.description: A slight or indirect indication or suggestion.
examples: he has given no hint of his views

verb.description: Suggest or indicate something indirectly or covertly.
examples: there were those who hinted at doctored evidence
Edwards has hinted that he will dispose of his majority shareholding
synonyms: make a reference to the fact

phrases: she tried to put him off but he didn't take the hint
As one should never address a surgeon directly in Spain, the columnist suggests trying to sing, hoping the surgeon takes the hint.
He took the hint, but sadly, things didn't get any better.
I took the hint and cut back on the hooch, and pretty soon the headache faded.
When the behavior continued, the compliance department took the hint and kept quiet.
origin: Early 17th century (in the sense occasion, opportunity): apparently from obsolete hent grasp, get hold of, from Old English hentan, of Germanic origin; related to hunt. The basic notion is something that may be taken advantage of.
